body: Watcher just triggers normal scans potentially within subdirs, so what you are describing doesn't add up. I suggest you enable scanner logs to see whats happening.

I now can reliably reproduce the issue. The described behavior is triggered, when *at some point in the present or past* exists a file whose name starts with a directory name. For example, the following will do:

    mkdir newdir3 && touch newdir3/newfile3 && touch newdir3.empty

After scanning is complete, remove the directory:

    rm -r newdir3

Note that newdir3/newfile3 is *not* marked as deleted. Also note that newdir3.empty can be deleted afterwards and the issue will be triggered again, without creating newdir3.empty again, so it seems even deleted files will be taken into account. (Which was the exact same situation like yesterday, sorry I didn't mention this earlier.)
Thanks, this looks like a bug.

body: Can't reproduce on linux, so I created a test for `IsDeleted` (not necessarily the culprit, but the prime suspect): #4936

Is there anything I can do to help? More logs or something like that? I would be happy to write a patch, but I have never worked with Go before and it may take some time until I understand the code good enough to hack. I am not even sure if I understand the test cases ...

By the way, I think the new title of the issue might be a bit mis-leading. A complete sync *will* recognize all deleted files. The issue I describe here only occurs by the partial scans that are triggered by FsWatcher, which is why I explicitly mentioned it in the original title. The issue persists until the next full scan, which is by default every hour when the Watcher is active. So the issue might be related to something the FsWatcher triggers.
